thread.title: MuleSoft Founder Connects with Salesforce in Massive Acquisition

author: Angus Loten
title: MuleSoft Founder Connects with Salesforce in Massive Acquisition
text:
0 COMMENTS Ross Mason speaks at MuleSoft Connect 2017 in San Francisco Photo: MuleSoft Inc.
MuleSoft Inc. is eyeing a broader role in corporate technology, from helping firms connect individual business software tools, to creating entire networks of reusable, integrated applications available to workers companywide, says founder Ross Mason.
The San Francisco-based API company, which was acquired by Salesforce.com Inc. in a $6.5 billion deal that closed last week, is best known for developing the pieces of software that enable firms to connect different data sources in their own data centers, the cloud, or both.
Delivered over a web-based service, MuleSoft’s APIs – which stands for application-programming interfaces – help companies stitch together a growing array of business applications and services, while unlocking valuable data trapped in older systems for use in newer tools, such as artificial intelligence and machine learning.
The 12-year-old company’s rise comes as most businesses have given up on finding a one-stop-shop IT vendor, choosing instead to mix and match business apps, cloud services and other tools from a range of competing tech providers, big and small.
In February, the company reported $296.5 million in total revenue for fiscal year 2017, up 58% from a year earlier.
Making all these tools work together can be a “living nightmare” for chief information officers, Mr. Mason says, adding that APIs alone have their limits.
He said integrated apps are so tightly bound together that other teams within the company often find they need new integrations to access the same set of applications for their own purposes.
Over time, a growing number of non-reusable integrations can become increasingly difficult for CIOs to manage: That’s where application networks come in, he said.
CIO Journal spoke with Mr. Mason, ahead of MuleSoft’s annual IT industry conference this week in San Jose, Calif. Edited excerpts below:
How are companies dealing with the pressure to make diverse business apps and data work together?
If you talk to any CIO, they’re feeling this across every sector of the economy. Companies are increasingly defined by the software that they run. The value that we provide to these organizations is by giving them a way to plug these things into each other in a way that gives them leverage over the capabilities in those apps. This is a massive challenge.
Big organizations are struggling, because in the past ten to 15 years, software practices have greatly improved and what we’re doing is helping enterprises retrofit their legacy tools with a much more modern architecture and approach.
What is the impact of juggling old and new IT tools on businesses or their customers?
Most IT organizations are in this loop where they’ve got to move faster, and do more projects, because there’s more software in the business. So the pressure is greater to move quickly and do things, like find a band-aid solution. And that’s starting to fail pretty significantly, which is why we have these big outages.
Every increment in efficiency, or providing better services and products to consumers, or having better employee services, hinges on being able to unlock data and capabilities around the enterprise.
What’s an application network and how does it help?
Scale and reuse is really important. Before us, you would do integration and it would serve its purpose but serve no other purpose, and that’s actually really expensive.
The capability that we define as reusable is this idea of an application network. The concept is pretty simple. Everything on the application network is pluggable. That means you can plug things in and plug them back out again. It’s a bit like a Cisco network, but for applications. So it’s not just about bringing new technology in, but connecting it to the old stuff so that you get the most value out of it.
What is the impact of the acquisition by Salesforce?
Things haven’t changed too much for us. The company is still being run by our CEO [Greg Schott]. We’re running the same vision and product strategy, before and after. The reason being is because what we’re doing is working. We connect everything, and one reason our customers like us is that we have strong neutrality to any applications or any platform.
We’re very focused on maintaining that neutrality. That makes a ton of sense for Salesforce and a ton of sense for us, because the data lives everywhere. You don’t want to be just about the piece of a sales cloud. You want to be able to reach everything, everywhere.
